Efficient and selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural catalyzed by metal porphyrin supported by alkaline lignin: Solvent optimization and catalyst loading Yuchen Zhu Visualization Investigation a Hao Wu Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft b Zheng Fang Project administration b d Xiaobing Yang c Kai Guo b d Wei He Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition c ⁎ a School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, China School of Pharmaceutical Sciences Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 China aSchool of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, China b College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, PR China College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 PR China bCollege of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, PR China c Biology and Medicine Department, Jiangsu Industrial Technology Research Institute, Nanjing 210031, PR China Biology and Medicine Department Jiangsu Industrial Technology Research Institute Nanjing 210031 PR China cBiology and Medicine Department, Jiangsu Industrial Technology Research Institute, Nanjing 210031, PR China d State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 PR China cState Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Cobalt (II)-meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by deprotected lignin was synthesized through the covalent linkage between carboxy groups in the porphyrin and hydroxyl groups in the lignin. The resulting supporting catalysts were applied in the selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. Through solvent optimization, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid could be selectively obtained. Steric effect of lignin prevented unwanted aggregation-caused quenching, avoiding catalyst deactivation. Thus, supported catalysts displayed better catalytic efficiency compared free metal porphyrin catalyst. Unlike the excessive use of sodium hydroxide in the oxidation of HMF catalyzed by metal catalysts, an equivalent amount of sodium hydroxide was used in this oxidation process. Meanwhile, lower activation energy was detected when metal porphyrin supported by deprotected lignin was used. By adjusting the pH in the reaction, supported catalysts could be reused. The catalytic activity remained stable during the recycling experiments. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin Porphyrin 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid Selective oxidation 1 Introduction Fossil fuels from oil, gas and coal are the predominant source for chemicals and energy. Although the utilization of fossil fuels accelerates economic and social development, some serious problems, such as resource depletion [1], global warming and air pollution [2,3], are gradually highlighted with the rapid consumption of fossil fuels. Among various renewable energies, biomass occupies the dominant position [4,5] due to abundant reserves and low price. Through a series of chemical transformations, biomass resources can be transformed into a variety of high-added chemicals and fuels, demonstrating tremendous potential to be the alternative for traditional fossil sources [6,7]. Generally, complex chemical reactions should be applied in the functionalization of petroleum molecules to introduce some functional groups [8]. However, inherent functional groups in the biomass simplify the chemical transformation. Thus, it is advisable to utilize biomass directly to obtain value-added chemicals. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), has been recognized as a biomass substrate compound due to the extensive application of its end products in the fuels, additives and functional polymers [9]. The hydroxyl group and formyl group in the furan ring endow high flexibility in the oxidation reaction, affording various oxidation products, such as 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 2,5furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [10]. Among these oxidation products, HMFCA and FDCA displayed potential applications in the functional polymers [11] through polymerization reaction due to the existence of carboxyl groups and hydroxyl groups. In addition, HMFCA also demonstrated excellent medicinal properties, such as antitumor activity [12]. Due to the molecular similarity to terephthalic acid, FDCA can be used as a monomer in the production of bio-based polymers and composites [13]. Bio-based polyesters from FDCA showed better performance compared with petroleum-based polyesters from terephthalic acid. Meanwhile, FDCA can also serves as versatile synthetic intermediates in plasticizers, pharmaceuticals and coordination polymers [14]. Thus, the exploration for more efficient methods for the preparation and utilization of HMFCA and FDCA has been attracting widespread attention from both academia and industry currently. Typically, the synthesis of FDCA consists of two oxidation process including the in-situ generation of oxidation intermediates and the oxidation of intermediates. Both intermediates (DFF and HMFCA) can be further oxidized to 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), which is finally transformed to FDCA. The synthetic route may be categorized into two classes according to the intermediates involved (Scheme 1 ) [15]. Various catalytic systems have been applied in this oxidation reaction, such as heterogeneous catalysts, homogeneous catalysts, and bio-catalysts [16]. Oxygen or air are normally preferred for HMF oxidation due to the broad availability, low price, and benignity to the environment [17,18]. Unlike the synthesis of FDCA, selective oxidation of the aldehyde group in HMF with reserved alcohol group is required in the synthesis of HMFCA. Generally, noble metal catalysts were used in the selective oxidation of HMF, affording HMFCA [19]. Other catalysts, such as immobilized molybdenum complex and photocatalysts, were also applied in the selective oxidation of HMF with a yield of 90-95% [20,21]. Similarly, metal catalysts (Au, Pd, Pt and Ru et al) occupied the main position in the oxidation of HMF for FDCA [22–25]. Meanwhile, pressurized molecular oxygen was the main oxidant in the oxidation of HMF for FDCA [26,27]. However, the application of metal catalysts increased the cost. Pressurized gas enlarged the risk of oxidation reaction. Thus, the development of effective, inexpensive, recyclable, and non-precious metal-based heterogeneous catalysts for the oxidation of HMF is still challenging and of enormous demands [15]. Porphyrins are biologically important pigments that accomplish versatile functions in biological systems, such as oxygen transport, photosynthesis, and enzyme catalytic centers [28]. The coordination of the metal ions into the porphyrin center affords metal porphyrin with multiple redox states, demonstrating impressive catalytic activity in broad chemical reactions, including oxidation, cycloaddition, and reduction [29]. Although metalloporphyrins are widely used in chemical catalysis, they are rarely used in the conversion of HMF. At present, only Lang chang et al. reported that HMF was selectively converted into FDCA with a yield up to 91% over Merrifield resin supported Co (II)-meso-tetra(4-pyridyl)-porphyrin catalyst [30]. However, strong oxidant tert-Butyl hydroperoxide was used in the oxidation. In addition, the highest yield of FDCA can be obtained only when the reaction temperature reaches 100 °C. In the oxidation process catalyzed by metalloporphyrins under oxygen atmosphere, oxidative decomposition, self-polymerization and deactivation of metalloporphyrins are ubiquitous. Non-covalent inter-molecular forces, such as π-π stacking aggregates, cause the risk of aggregation-caused quenching, resulting in decreased catalytic activity [31]. Thus, chemical transformations are necessary for maintaining the catalytic activity of metalloporphyrins. Lignin, a heterogeneous phenylpropanoid polymer, is currently the only feasible renewable feedstock for aromatic compounds. Due to the high abundance in aromatic ring, lignin displayed high steric hindrance. The combination of lignin and metalloporphyrins prevents aggregation and the related aggregation-caused quenching [31] through kinetic study. Cobalt (II)-meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by Deprotected Lignin (DL-CoTCPP) was synthesized from alkali lignin by chemical bonding porphyrin. The catalyst was prepared and used for the oxidation of HMF into HMFCA and FDCA. To our knowledge, this is the first article to selectively prepare HMFCA and FDCA by regulating solvents. Meanwhile, reaction kinetics was also conducted to analyzed the oxidation process. The activation energies of supported catalysts and free catalysts were determined to reveal the role of lignin. Catalyst recovery process was designed to improve the sustainability. Catalyst recycling experiments were carried out to evaluate the availability of reusing. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pyrrole, methyl p-formylbenzoate, triphenylphosphine and diethyl azodicarboxylate, all metal chloride salts were reagent grade and provided by Aladdin Corp. (Shanghai, China). HMF was purchased from Beijing Chemicals Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China). Oxidation products of HMF (FDCA and HMFCA) were analytical grade and supplied by J&K Chemical Co., Ltd., (Beijing, China). Alkaline lignin was provided by Xiangjiang Paper Industry Co., Ltd. (Hunan, China). Alkaline lignin was acidified and purified through filtration with ultrapure water. 2.2 Synthesis of meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (TCPP) Pyrrole (3.0 g, 0.043 mol) and methyl p-formylbenzoate (6.9 g, 0.042 mol) were put into a 250 ml Pyrrole (3.0 g, 0.043 mol), methyl p-formylbenzoate (6.9 g, 0.042 mol) and propionic acid (100 mL) were added into a three-neck flask (250 mL). The reaction was conducted at 150 °C for 12 h. After reaction, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, yielding black solid. After filtration, the solid was washed with ethanol and dried in vacuum to obtain purple porphyrin ester precursor. The precursor (1.95 g) was dissolved in a mixed solvent (120 mL, tetrahydrofuran / methanol=1:1). 60ml 2M KOH aqueous solution was added into the mixed solvent. The mixture was heated at 80 °Cfor 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was acidified with 1M HCl solution until no solid was produced. Meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin was obtained through washing operation and drying treatment. Meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (violet crystal, 32.3%). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ 2.87 ppm (2H, N-H), δ 8.39 ppm (8H, phenyl), δ 8.45 ppm (8H, phenyl), δ 8.91 ppm (8H, pyrrole). 2.3 Preparation of deprotected lignin (DL) Demethylation of alkaline lignin was carried out based on the previous study [32]. In brief, alkaline lignin (5 g) was dissolved in DMF solution (20 mL). Then, HBr solution (48%, 25 g) was added into the mixture. The demethylation was conducted at 120 °C for 20 h. After cooling to room temperature, HCl solution (2 M, 2.5 L) was added dropwise, yielding black precipitate. The precipitate was obtained through centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 15 min. Through washing operation and drying treatment, black DL powder was obtained in a yield of 71.2%. The Mw of the deprotected lignin (DL) was estimated to be 5732 with a polydispersity index of 1.16. The contents of elemental carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen of DL were measured to be 45.18, 4.36, and 50.46wt% respectively. 2.4 Preparation of meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by DL (DL-TCPP) Meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by DL was synthesized according to a previously described method with modifications [31]. Initially, Deprotected Lignin (0.5 g), meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (0.3 g) and triphenylphosphine (0.24 g) were dissolved in DMF (15 mL). When the solid was dissolved, diethyl azodicarboxylate (0.3 mL) was added dropwise. Then, the reaction was conducted at 65 °C for 12 h. The final solution was transferred to a dialysis bag (MW = 1000 Da) and dialyzed in DMF to remove triphenylphosphine oxide and unreacted porphyrin. The meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by DL with a yield of 78% was obtained through freeze-drying for 36h. 2.5 Synthesis of cobalt (II)-meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by DL (DL-CoTCPP) Cobalt (II)-meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by DL was prepared through the coordination reaction between DL-TCPP (1.0 g) and cobalt (II) acetate (0.2 g) in DMF (10 mL). The reaction was refluxed for 4 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was poured into distilled water (50 mL). The solid-liquid mixture was stirred for 2 h. The precipitate was filtered and washed with H2O. Finally, the obtained solid was dried, affording cobalt (II)-meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by DL (purple black powder) with a yield of 84%. 2.6 Characterization of catalyst 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra of the products were recorded on a JEOL ECZ500R 400 MHz NMR spectrometer using DMSO-d6 as the solvent at 25 °C. The molecular weights and polydispersity index were measured by using gel permeation chromatography (GPC). The GPC instrument was equipped a PL gel 5 μm mixed-D column. The measurements were carried out at 25 °C with DMF as the eluent (1.0 mL/min). Molecular weights were calibrated with polystyrene standards. Elemental analysis of C, H, O and N was conducted using an Elementar Vario EL cube. The UV-vis spectra of samples were measured using an Agilent Cary 300 UV-vis spectrophotometer. HMF and its derivatives in samples were analyzed by High Performance Liquid Chromatography with a Aminex®HPX-87H column (300 × 7.8 mm) using aqueous sulfuric acid (5 mM) as mobile phase at the flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. The column oven temperature was kept at 25 °C. The content of HMF, HMFCA and FDCA in samples were calculated by the external standard method. HMF conversion = moles of converted HMF moles of initial HMF × 100 % HMFCA yield = moles of HMFCA moles of initial HMF × 100 % FDCA yield = moles of FDCA moles of initial HMF × 100 % 2.7 HMF oxidation 2.7.1 General procedures for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to HMFCA Typically, 50 mg HMF (0.4 mmol), 16 mg NaOH (0.4 mmol), 10 mg catalyst, and 5 mL acetonitrile were added into a pressure-resistant tube (15 mL). The reaction was conducted at 15 °C in an air atmosphere for 12 h. HMF and its derivatives in samples were analyzed by HPLC with Aminex®HPX-87H column (300 × 7.8 mm) using aqueous sulfuric acid (5 mM) as mobile phase at the flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. 2.7.2 General procedures for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA Typically, 50 mg HMF (0.4 mmol), 16 mg NaOH (0.4 mmol), 10 mg catalyst, and 5 mL DMF were added into a pressure-resistant tube (25 ml). The tube was purged with O2 for 6–8 times. Finally, the reactant mixture was stirred at 15 °C in an oxygen atmosphere for 24 h. HMF and its derivatives in samples were analyzed by HPLC with Aminex®HPX-87H column (300 × 7.8 mm) using aqueous sulfuric acid (5 mM) as mobile phase at the flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The procedure for preparing DL-CoTCPP was illustrated in Scheme 2 . Firstly, TCPP was prepared by reacting pyrrole with methyl p-formylbenzoate in the presence of propanoic acid. Phenolic and aliphatic hydroxyl groups in Deprotected Lignin could react with carboxylic groups in the TCPP to form ester bonds, affording DL-TCPP [31]. The coordination between Co2+ and TCPP was realized through the reaction of Co(OAc)2 with TCPP at reflux temperature, yielding DL-CoTCPP. The possible structure of DL-CoTCPP was showed in Fig. 1 . The 1H NMR spectra of DL, TCPP, and DL-CoTCPP were recorded and presented in Fig. 2 . In the spectrum of DL-CoTCPP, aliphatic proton signals at about 0.7–1.2 ppm were reserved. In addition to the aromatic signals from lignin, two additional peaks were observed in the spectrum. One peak was located at 8.3–8.5 ppm, which can be assigned to the protons in the benzene ring of CoTCPP. The other peak was located at 9.21 ppm, which can be assigned to the protons in the pyrrole ring of CoTCPP. In the DL-CoTCPP spectrum, the chemical shift of pyrrole ring protons moves up-field and the chemical shift of the benzene ring protons remains the same. This is mainly due to the phenyl moieties in DL-CoTCPP exerting the shielding effect on the surrounding chromophores [31] and the paramagnetism of the unpaired electrons of the cobalt ion causes the resonance signal width to increase [33]. Furthermore, the UV-vis spectra of DL, CoTCPP, and DL-CoTCPP in DMF were shown in Fig. 3 . The characteristic Soret band in the range of 400–450 nm from CoTCPP and the absorption band in the range of 270–290 nm from lignin were still observed in the spectra of DL-CoTCPP. This result indicated that the ground state properties of porphyrin moieties were not alerted significantly [31]. In addition, the combination of characteristic absorption peak from CoTCPP and DL in the spectra of DL-CoTCPP demonstrated that CoTCPP and DL were linked together by covalent bonds. To quantify the degree of functionalization (DF) in DL-CoTCPP [34], elemental analysis was performed to detect nitrogen content in the sample. The results were listed in Table 1 . DL used in this study was estimated to be 5732 by GPC with a polydispersity index of 1.16. The methoxyl group content is 7.38% [35]. Based on the elemental and functional group analysis, the average phenyl-propanoid unit (C9 unit) of DL was calculated to be C9H9.32O7.44(OCH3)0.61, with a monomer molecular weight of 255.24. The DF was calculated according to Eq. (1). (1) N % ≈ DF × 14 × n N M w , unit + DF × M w , n N% is the mole content of nitrogen in lignin-based polymers. Mw,unit is the molecular weight of the DL unit. Mw,n is the molecular weight of the end-group, which is 841.93 for CoTCPP. nN is the number of nitrogens in the end-group, which is 4 for CoTCPP. In the study, the mole content of nitrogen in lignin-based polymers was 2.99% (N%= 2.99%). The DF value of DL-CoTCPP was 24.16% when the value of N% was substituted into Eq. (1). 3.2 Solvent optimization for selective oxidation The oxidation of HMF in different solvents were shown in Table 2 . It could be seen from Table 2 that the solvent played a significant role on the conversion and selectivity. The yield of FDCA was higher in DMSO and DMF. Compared with DMSO, the oxidation of HMF in DMF displayed better selectivity for FDCA in the air. When the oxidant was changed from air atmosphere to oxygen atmosphere, the selectivity for FDCA was increased from 39.19 to 67.3 (Table 2, Entries 2 and 8). In addition, obvious difference in the selectivity for HMFCA was observed when the solvent in the oxidation of HMF was altered. Higher selectivity was obtained when the reaction was conducted in acetonitrile and tetrahydrofuran. Relatively higher selectivity for HMFCA was displayed in acetonitrile. Interestingly, when the reaction temperature was 50 °C, the selectivity for HMFCA was 67.43 (Table 2, Entry 3). When the temperature was decreased to 15 °C, obvious increase in the selectivity was detected (Table 2, Entry 7). Thus, the oxidation of HMF for HMFCA was conducted in acetonitrile in the air atmosphere, while the oxidation of HMF for FDCA was conducted in DMF in the oxygen atmosphere. The procedure for selective preparation of HMFCA and FDCA was illustrated in Scheme 3 . 3.3 The relationship between solvent nature and reaction selectivity The effect of dielectric constant and the donor number (DN) on the reaction selectivity was investigated. No obvious relationship between dielectric constant and reaction selectivity was observed. However, two contradictory trends concerning DN were merged in the oxidation of HMF (Fig. 4 ). DN is an index of the solvent basicity, demonstrating the ability to donate electrons [36]. In other words, solvents with high DN mean high basicity. Solvents with high DN are expected to promote the improvement in the electron density of the substrates, rendering the substrate more susceptible to oxidation [37]. When HMFCA was the target product, solvents with relatively low DN were beneficial for the formation of HMFCA. On the contrary, solvents with relatively high DN promoted the synthesis of FDCA. DN and the ability to be oxidized have close relation with each other. HMFCA was one of the intermediate products in the oxidation process of HMF. The further oxidation of HMFCA would yield more FDCA. Thus, solvents with low DN would promote the appropriate improvement in the electron density and partial oxidation of HMF, yielding HMFCA. Solvents with high DN would promote adequate improvement in the electron density and complete oxidation of HMF, yielding FDCA. Of course, appropriate DN was necessary for the formation of FDCA allowing for the high instability of furan rings. Dipolarity (π*) and hydrogen bond accepting ability (β) are two other indexes of solvent nature [38,39]. The effect of these two indexes on the reaction selectivity was also investigated. No obvious relationship between dipolarity and reaction selectivity was observed. However, two contradictory trends concerning hydrogen bond accepting ability were merged in the oxidation of HMF (Fig. 5 ). Solvents with relatively low β values promoted the formation of HMFCA, while solvents with relatively high β values are beneficial for the synthesis of FDCA. A similar trend was also observed in the relationship between DN and reaction selectivity. These results indicated that hydrogen bond had involved in the oxidation of HMF. 3.4 Catalytic oxidation of HMF into HMFCA The aerobic oxidation of HMF into HMFCA was carried out at different temperatures. As shown in Table 3 , the temperature showed a remarkable effect on the oxidation of HMF. When the reaction temperature was 15 °C, HMF was completely transformed with a selectivity of 94.7% (Table 3, Entry 2). When temperature was increased to 70 °C, the yield of HMFCA decreased from 94.7% to 40.8% (Table 3, Entries 2–5). When the reaction temperature was decreased to 0 °C, both the conversion of HMF and the yield of HMFCA decreased (Table 3, Entry 1). Overall, the increase of reaction temperature in the oxidation of HMF for HMFCA promoted the conversion of HMF. However, reaction temperature was parabolic correlated to the selectivity for HMFCA. Therefore, 15°C was selected as the optimal reaction temperature. The aerobic oxidation of HMF into HMFCA was also carried out with various amounts of catalyst in order to study the effect of the catalyst loading. As shown in Table 4 , the loading of catalyst showed a remarkable effect on the aerobic oxidation of HMF into HMFCA. When no catalyst DL-CoTCPP was added, the conversion of HMF was 36.01% (Table 4, Entry 1). When the amount of DL-CoTCPP was 2.5 mg, the HMFCA yield and HMF conversion increased significantly, with the conversion of 73.84% and the yield of 68.78% (Table 4, Entry 2). As the amount of the added catalyst increased, the conversion of HMF and the yield of HMFCA gradually increased. It should be attributed to an increase in the availability and number of catalytically active sites [40]. When the catalyst content was 10mg, the conversion of HMF and yield of HMFCA reached the highest level. Further increase of the catalyst content yielded constant conversion and yield (Table 4, Entries 3–6). As displayed in Scheme 1, the oxidation process of HMF was complicated with various oxidation products. Two reaction pathways might exist in the oxidation process. In order to better understand the process of HMF oxidation into HMFCA over DL-CoTCPP catalyst, the distribution of oxidation products at different reaction time points were recorded. The results were shown in Fig. 6 . It could be seen from the Fig. 6, HMF was rapidly consumed within the initial four hours, with a conversion of 53.95%. No HMF was detected after 12 h. With the extension of reaction time, the yield of HMFCA increased gradually. When the reaction time was extended to 12 h, the maximum yield of HMFCA was 94.70%. Obviously, slight amount of FFCA and FDCA was observed when the oxidation of HMF was conducted. Notably, no DFF was detected. The distinct reaction pathway could be attributed to the preferential adsorption of −CHO group in the structure of HMF on the basic and positive surface of DL-CoTCPP [41]. 3.5 Catalytic oxidation of HMF into FDCA The aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA was carried out at different temperatures. As shown in Table 5 , the temperature showed a remarkable effect on the oxidation of HMF for FDCA. When the reaction temperature was set to be 0 °C, both HMF conversion and FDCA yield were relatively low (Table 5, Entry 1). The yield of FDCA reach the highest when the reaction temperature was 15 °C (Table 5, Entry 2). Meanwhile, slight HMFCA was detected at this temperature. Subsequently, the further increase of reaction temperature resulted in less FDCA (Table 5, Entries 2–5). More HMFCA was observed with higher temperature. On the contrary, the reaction temperature was parabolic correlated to the yield of FDCA. Initially, increased temperature accelerated the formation of FDCA. However, further increase in the reaction temperature went against the oxidation reaction of HMF for FDCA. Interestingly, the total yield of HMFCA and FDCA was almost consistent. The decreased yield of FDCA was accompanied by the increase in the yield of HMFCA. Thus, higher temperature might be adverse to the oxidation of HMFCA into FDCA. The oxidation of aldehyde group in the HMF into HMFCA was relatively easy to be realized. However, high activity of oxidation catalyst was necessary in the preparation of FDCA from HMFCA including two oxidation reactions. At higher temperature, agglomeration of part metalloporphyrin might be occurred, resulting in catalyst deactivation [42]. Thus, no adequate active catalyst existed in the oxidation process, leading to low yield. In addition, higher temperature went against the improvement of oxygen solubility. Thus, low solubility of oxygen at high temperature also resulted in insufficient dissolved oxygen in the organic solvent, resulting in incomplete oxidation of HMFCA [43]. In summary, 15 °C is the most suitable reaction temperature for the preparation of FDCA by HMF oxidation. Meanwhile, obvious difference between DL-CoTCPP catalyst and CoTCPP catalyst demonstrated that supported metalloporphyrin displayed better catalytic efficiency. On one hand, agglomeration of metalloporphyrin could be suppressed due to the existence of DL with larger steric hindrance [31]. On the other hand, the preparation of DL-CoTCPP included the self-assembly process of DL [32], affording DL-CoTCPP with large specific surface area. Thus, DL-CoTCPP prepared in this study promoted the interaction between reactants and catalysts, improving the reaction efficiency. The aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA was also carried out with various amounts of catalyst in order to study the effect of the catalyst loading. As shown in Table 6 , the loading of catalyst played an important role in the aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA. The yield of FDCA was only 26.60% with a conversion of 37.85% without the addition of DL-CoTCPP catalyst (Table 6, Entry 1). When 2.5 mg DL-CoTCPP was added, the yield of FDCA and HMF conversion increased significantly with the yield of 41.68% and the conversion of 56.78% (Table 6, Entry 2). With the further increase of the catalyst amount, the yield of FDCA and the conversion of HMF increased obviously. Meanwhile, the yield of HMFCA decreased. This phenomenon was consistent with the results concerning reaction temperature in the oxidation of HMF for FDCA. Catalyst deactivation resulted in insufficient active catalyst at high temperature, yielding more residual HMFCA in the process. When more DL-CoTCPP catalyst was added into the oxidation reaction, less HMFCA was detected. When the catalyst amount was 10 mg, the yield of FDCA and the conversion of HMF reached the highest. Constant yield and conversion were observed with more catalyst (Table 6, Entries 3–6). This result was the same as the previous research concerning HMFCA by catalytic oxidation of HMF. In order to better understand the process of HMF oxidation into FDCA over DL-CoTCPP catalyst, the distribution of oxidation products at different reaction time points were recorded. The results were shown in Fig. 7 . As could be seen from the Fig. 7, HMF was rapidly consumed within the initial 8 h, with a conversion of 95.78%. The yield of FDCA increased with the increase in the reaction time. After 24 h, the yield of FDCA was 71.24%. Subsequently, constant yield was observed with extend reaction time. When the reaction time was up to 8 h, the conversion of HMF reached the highest level. Meanwhile, the highest yields of HMFCA and FFCA were detected. More HMFCA was observed compared with FFCA, demonstrating that the oxidation of FFCA was easier than the oxidation of HMFCA. In the whole process, no DFF was detected. Therefore, the reasonable reaction pathway of HMF oxidation over DL-CoTCPP also followed Path 2 (HMF→HMFCA→ FFCA→ FDCA) as depicted in Scheme 1. 3.6 The reaction kinetics in the oxidation of HMF The reaction kinetics in the oxidation of HMF into HMFCA and FDCA was studied in detail. According to the preliminary optimization results, the variation trend concerning the conversion of HMF with different temperature and reaction time was further investigated. The reaction temperature displayed a remarkable effect on the catalytic performance (Fig. 8 a, d, g, j). Furthermore, ln (Ct/C0) followed a linear relationship with the reaction time at low conversion of HMF. By calculating the corresponding slope of the plots, the reaction rate constants were calculated (Fig. 8 b, e, h, k). According to Arrhenius formula, the regression equation was plotted with 1000/RT as the x-coordinate and lnK as the y-coordinate. The apparent activation energy concerning DL-CoTCPP catalyst and CoTCPP catalyst in the oxidation of HMF for HMFCA and FDCA could be obtained through mathematical calculation. The apparent activation energies of DL-CoTCPP in the oxidation of HMF for HMFCA and FDCA were 17.764 KJ/mol and 11.205 KJ/mol, respectively. In addition, the apparent activation energies of CoTCPP in the oxidation of HMF for HMFCA and FDCA were 18.554 KJ/mol and 18.557 KJ/mol, respectively (Fig. 8 c, f, i, l). Obvious decreased in the activation energies was observed when the free CoTCPP was bound to DL. Meanwhile, higher yield was detected when supported DL-CoTCPP was added into the oxidation process. On one hand, supported DL-CoTCPP with large specific surface area was obtained through self-assembly of DL, promoting the interaction between catalysts and reactants. On the other hand, larger O* amount and better dispersion of active oxygen species would be realized in the DL-CoTCPP, resulting in the improvement in catalytic activity [44]. 3.7 Catalyst recycling experiments The catalyst recycling experiments were investigated. The procedure for recycling DL-CoTCPP was illustrated in Scheme 4 . The reactions were carried out in CH3CN and DMF at 15 °C, respectively. After reaction, 2 M HCl was added dropwise into the reaction mixture until no solid were generated. Then the solid-liquid mixture was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 5 min. The obtained solid was washed three times with ethanol and water and dried at 60 °C overnight in a vacuum oven. The recovered catalyst was used for the second cycle under the same conditions. These processes were repeated for five times to test the stability of the catalyst. As shown in Figs. 9 and 10 , the yields of HMFCA (94.7% in first cycle vs 90.1% in sixth cycle) and the yields of FDCA (71.24% in first cycle vs 69.12% in sixth cycle) remained stable during the recycling experiments. These results indicate that DL-CoTCPP catalyst was recyclable and stable for selective oxidation of HMF into HMFCA and FDCA. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a novel supported metal porphyrin was developed for the oxidation of HMF into HMFCA and FDCA. The catalyst can selectively oxidize HMF to prepare HMFCA and FDCA by solvent selection. Under optimized reaction conditions, the catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic performance with HMFCA yield of 94.7% and FDCA yield of 71.24%. High temperature, high pressure, high concentration alkaline were not necessary in the oxidation process. Air or oxygen at ambient pressure was used as the oxidant. An equivalent amount of sodium hydroxide was applied in the oxidation, avoiding its excessive use. The metal porphyrin supported by deprotected lignin displayed better catalytic efficiency compared with free metal porphyrin. Lower activation energy was detected with supported catalysts. The integration of solvent optimization and catalyst loading promoted the selective oxidation of HMF, affording HMFCA and FDCA with high selectivity. In addition, the catalyst can be easily separated from the reaction mixture by acid precipitation without the loss of its catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt (II)-meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin supported by deprotected lignin was synthesized through the covalent linkage between carboxy groups in the porphyrin and hydroxyl groups in the lignin. The resulting supporting catalysts were applied in the selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. Through solvent optimization, 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid could be selectively obtained. Steric effect of lignin prevented unwanted aggregation-caused quenching, avoiding catalyst deactivation. Thus, supported catalysts displayed better catalytic efficiency compared free metal porphyrin catalyst. Unlike the excessive use of sodium hydroxide in the oxidation of HMF catalyzed by metal catalysts, an equivalent amount of sodium hydroxide was used in this oxidation process. Meanwhile, lower activation energy was detected when metal porphyrin supported by deprotected lignin was used. By adjusting the pH in the reaction, supported catalysts could be reused. The catalytic activity remained stable during the recycling experiments.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient and selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural catalyzed by metal porphyrin supported by alkaline lignin: Solvent optimization and catalyst loading
